University of Chicago Crime Lab
SDSC (Strategic Decision Support Center)
During my time at the University of Chicago I primarily worked on the SDSC project. I started out as a crime analyst for 3 CPD districts in the Bureau of Patrol and provided advice and data insight for the Commanders while assisted in different capacities for many other districts across the city. Afterwards, I worked as the Area South Deputy Chief Analyst for the Area South Deputy Chief while simultaneously taking on the role of ATC (Area Technology Center) Analyst for the Area South Detectives (The ATC is essentially the Bureau of Detectivesâ€™ version of SDSC, though with vastly different tools, equipment, and procedures). Following crime focused work I would move from to the CPD HQ to work on a number of traffic,personnel, and consent decree related data work.

SDSC was recognized by the Integrated Justice Information Systems (NJIS) Institute and received the 2021 Thomas J. Oâ€™Reilly Innovation Award at its 2021 National SYmposium: [award article]
City of Chicago Office of the Mayor: Violent Reduction Dashboard
One critical component of my work with the Chicago Office of the Mayor was the Regional Coordination Meeting where I was in charge of the South Side data while another colleague was in charge of the West Side. The goal of the meeting was to identify and tackle violent crimes and related issues with a wide range of agencies and organizations, including UChicago Crime Lab (with myself as representative), UChicago Medicine, Chicago Police Dept, Chicago Mayorâ€™s Office, Chicago Dept of Street and Sanitation, Chicago Park District, Cook COunty Stateâ€™s Attorneyâ€™s Office, Chicago CRED, and a number of other public agencies and outreach non-profits.
The bi-weekly meetings required myself and the other analyst to manually produce a bi-weekly data/ stats packet to reflect the number of fatal shootings, non-fatal shootings, and non-shooting homicides. As time went on, we realized there should be a better way of showing the crime analytics, thus the VR dashboard was born. The beta version received approval from the Chicago former Deputy Mayor of Public Safety Susan Lee and former US Secretary of Education Arne Duncan and our team continued to polish the dashboard. After about 6 months of work, the VR Dashboard was officially launched on the City of Chicagoâ€™s Website as the first ever public data dashboard in the city. As one of the two analysts who created the dashboard, I also produced monthly update/troubleshooting newsletter, training and presenting the dashboard to a wide range of public agencies, outreach organizations, and other stakeholders, and designing the cover page and base map of the dashboard.

A couple screenshots of the dashboard, made in Tableau and Tableau PrepAs of May 27th, 2021, the VR Dashboard is officially open to the public:

Chicago Police Dept. Consent Decree
I had the opportunity of working on a series of projects under the Consent Decree, which is essentially a federal mandate set forth by the US Department of Justice to reform law enforcement agencies. The consent decree had already been implemented in a number of police departments across the US, including the LAPD, Seattle PD, and NOPD, before arriving in Chicago in 2017. Much of the work is focused on building community-police relationship, improving resource/patrol efficiency, and examining personnel data on absences/furloughs among others.
For background information on Chicago Police Consent Decree please see: [Illinois Attorney General] | [CPD Independent Monitor Team] | [City of Chicago]
